heading: 1. Welcome and Course Overview
text:
Welcome Energy Transitions Seminar. course learning think like data analyst R working real data energy transition. week, ‚Äôll alternate short explanations hands-practice. see new function concept, try understand two things: (1) , (2) ‚Äôs right tool job. end, ‚Äôll comfortable loading data, cleaning , summarizing , visualizing relationships, fitting introductory econometric models.‚Äôll use FinSESCo dataset, explores households behave invest energy efficiency.
Throughout course ‚Äôll:handle real-world data,explore variables,build econometric models step--step.Everything hands-‚Äî ‚Äôll code, test, visualize results.

heading: Installing R and RStudio
text: Download install:RRStudio DesktopWhen open RStudio, ‚Äôll see four panels:Source (top-left): scripts markdown.Console (bottom-left): executes commands.Environment / History (top-right): lists objects.Files / Plots / Packages / Help (bottom-right): navigation tools.

heading: üí° Tip
text: RStudio shortcuts speed : Run line (Ctrl + Enter), Comment/Uncomment (Ctrl + Shift + C), Find/Replace (Ctrl + F).

heading: Installing Packages
text:
R‚Äôs power comes packages ‚Äî sets functions add ‚Äúbase R.‚Äù
Use install.packages("name_of_the_package") per machine download , library(name_of_the_package) session load .example, tidyverse bundle gives : dplyr (data manipulation), ggplot2 (visualization), readr (fast import). ‚Äôll see often standardize syntax make code readable.
code:
install.packages("tidyverse")   # only once## Error in install.packages : Updating loaded packages
library(tidyverse)              # every session

heading: üí° Tip
text: see error like "package called 'dplyr'", install first install.packages("dplyr"), load library(dplyr).

heading: Working Directory
text:
working directory folder R reads writes default.
projects books, avoid setwd(...). Instead, use project-relative paths (e.g., via package) code works computer without editing file paths.getwd() -> shows current folder
setwd() -> set pathe.g.¬†setwd(‚ÄúC:/Users/Renan/Documents/finsesco_course‚Äù)

heading: üìù Good practice
text: Keep clean structure like data/, images/, scripts/. Load files paths ::("data", "finSESCo_sample.csv").

heading: 2. Variable Assignment & Basic Data Types
text:
Everything R object. create update objects assignment (prefer left-arrow "<-" idiomatic visually distinctive). example, assign number x, string name, boolean sunny.R stores values types:
- numeric (e.g., 3.14) continuous numbers,
- integer (e.g., 10L) whole numbers,
- character (e.g., "Berlin") text,
- logical (TRUE/FALSE),
- factor labeled categories (internally stored integers + levels).can inspect types class(x) (high-level label) typeof(x) (internal storage).
can also convert types .numeric(), .character(), .logical(), .factor(). called coercion essential cleaning survey data might come text.inspecting variables, see y character. Therefore get error making operations . considered text, number x.Therefore, convert y numeric want make operations x.Try :Type conversion:
code:
x <- 30
y <- '50' # character on purpose
name <- "Renan"
sunny <- FALSE
class(x)## [1] "numeric"
class(y)## [1] "character"
x + y## Error in x + y: non-numeric argument to binary operator
y_1 <- as.numeric(y)
z <- x + y_1
z## [1] 80
temperature <- c(18, 20, 23, 21)
is.numeric(temperature)## [1] TRUE
as.numeric("5")## [1] 5
as.character(123)## [1] "123"
as.factor(c("low", "high", "low"))## [1] low  high low 
## Levels: high low

heading: üí° Tip
text: R case-sensitive: Income income different objects. Prefer lower_case_names names (e.g., mean_income).

heading: 3. Working with R Objects
text: R‚Äôs data structures building blocks analysis:Vectors: one-dimensional, type. Use c(...) combine values functions like length(), mean(), indexing [].Matrices: two-dimensional, type. Useful linear algebra certain algorithms; ‚Äôll likely just recognize Week 1.Factors: categorical variables explicit levels (e.g., "low", "medium", "high"). Factors crucial modeling plotting categories.Data frames: tables column vector length. main workhorse empirical work. Functions like nrow(), names(), str() help understand structure.Lists: containers can mix types (model fit often returns list: coefficients, residuals, fitted values, etc.). Use $ [[ ]] access elements.tidyverse elevates data frames tibbles, print nicely behave consistently.Table 1: Basic Data Types R

heading: i) Vectors
text: vector one-dimensional collection elements type. Vectors fundamental building block R.can access elements position (1-based indexing) perform vectorized operations:
code:
# Creating numeric, character, and logical vectors
v_num  <- c(10, 20, 30, 40)
v_chr  <- c("east", "west", "north")
v_log  <- c(TRUE, FALSE, TRUE)
v_num## [1] 10 20 30 40
v_chr## [1] "east"  "west"  "north"
v_log## [1]  TRUE FALSE  TRUE
# Indexing (1-based)
v_num[1]          # first element## [1] 10
v_num[2:3]        # elements 2 through 3## [1] 20 30
v_num[c(1, 4)]    # elements 1 and 4## [1] 10 40
# Vectorized math
v_num + 5## [1] 15 25 35 45
v_num * 2## [1] 20 40 60 80
v_num / v_num     # element-wise division## [1] 1 1 1 1

heading: ii) Matrices
text: matrix 2D collection (rows √ó columns) type.

heading: iii) Factors
text: Factors represent categorical variables (levels).
code:
gender <- factor(c("Male", "Female", "Female"))
levels(gender)## [1] "Female" "Male"
table(gender)## gender
## Female   Male 
##      2      1

heading: iv) Data Frames
text: data frame table column vector equal length.
code:
df <- data.frame(
  id = 1:3,
  income = c(2000, 3500, 2800),
  region = c("East", "West", "West")
)
head(df)
str(df)## 'data.frame':    3 obs. of  3 variables:
##  $ id    : int  1 2 3
##  $ income: num  2000 3500 2800
##  $ region: chr  "East" "West" "West"
###Basic subsetting:

df$income## [1] 2000 3500 2800
df[ , "region"]## [1] "East" "West" "West"
df[ df$income > 2500, ]

heading: v) Lists
text: list can store elements different types (useful model results).
code:
person <- list(
  name = "Renan",
  age = 31,
  instruments = c("Guitar", "Bass")
)
person$instruments## [1] "Guitar" "Bass"
person[[1]]      # first element of the list## [1] "Renan"

heading: 4. Exploring Your Dataset
text:
Let‚Äôs import FinSESCo dataset
(‚Äôve downloaded .csv file course repository.)seminar, ‚Äôll analyze curated sample FinSESCo survey. dataset collected survey company Norstat 28 Aug 2023 23 Nov 2023 study energy-efficiency behaviors, demand-side flexibility, (co-)ownership patterns among German households. design intentionally broadened representation female low-income prosumers relative earlier waves, aiming balanced view across demographics. panel sampling approach means national proportions prosumers inferred, survey targeted representativeness age, gender, state population distributions, adjustments later fieldwork reach specific groups interest. :contentReferenceoaicite:0Sample size: 2,585 completed questionnairesProsumers: 925 individuals (including 464 women)
scale enables comparisons prosumers non-prosumers within prosumer subgroups (e.g., income gender). :contentReferenceoaicite:1Key constructs & questions ‚Äôll use later:
- Willingness invest electricity/heating efficiency measures (past actions score + planned actions score).
- Familiarity Energy Savings (Performance) Contracting intention use FinSESCo-like platform (transformed ‚Äì3‚Ä¶+3 analytical indices).
- Drivers (motivations financial, environmental, knowledge, climate concern, energy autonomy, selling excess energy) Likert scales.
- Context & demographics: (co-)ownership, income category, age, gender, education, . :contentReferenceoaicite:2When import tabular data, always sanity-check:
- Preview first rows (look like clean table?).
- Structure: variable names, types (numeric? character? factor?).
- Missing values: many ?
- Ranges: minima/maxima make sense?R, ‚Äôll use functions like head(), str(), summary(), dplyr::glimpse() overview.
survey data, expect missing values (NA). Many functions accept na.rm = TRUE compute summaries observed values . forget , single NA can make whole summary become NA.Start exploring structure:‚Äôll get sense variables ‚Äî maybe income_range, age, education, etc.üí° Tip: see NA, means ‚Äúmissing data.‚Äù can remove ignore na.rm = TRUE functions.

heading: üî¥ Important
text: variable might look numeric stored character (e.g., due non-standard entries). Check class() coerce thoughtfully .numeric() cleaning.

heading: 5. Descriptive Statistics
text:
Descriptive statistics tell data looks like modeling:
- Central tendency: mean() median() (median robust outliers).
- Spread: sd() (standard deviation) interquartile range.
- Distribution shape: histograms boxplots detect skewness outliers.
- Counts proportions: table() factors; grouped summaries categories.dplyr, flow :group ‚Üí summarise ‚Üí arrange (optionally mutate compute new columns).
example, might compute average energy spending income group share respondents report specific behavior ownership type‚Äîfirst steps toward answering research questions.Let‚Äôs compute simple summaries.Using dplyr, can group:
code:
mean(finsesco$index_1, na.rm = TRUE)## [1] 4.281382
median(finsesco$index_1, na.rm = TRUE)## [1] 4.4
sd(finsesco$index_1, na.rm = TRUE)## [1] 0.7211005
finsesco %>%
  group_by(income_range) %>%
  summarise(mean_index_1 = mean(index_1, na.rm = TRUE))

heading: 0.1.0.1 üìù Interpretation mindset
text: two groups differ means, ask: difference large enough matter? Stable across subgroups? Driven outliers? Plotting complements tables revealing distribution shape potential leverage points.

heading: Your First Plot
text:
Plots compact summaries. Week 1, mainly use:
- Histogram (one numeric variable): distribution, skew, possible heaping.
- Boxplot (numeric vs.¬†category): medians, spread, outliers across groups.
- Bar chart (counts summary statistics): proportions aggregated metrics across categories.later weeks, ‚Äôll refine adding confidence intervals, transforming axes (e.g., log scale), layering multiple aesthetics compare subgroups (e.g., income ownership).‚Äôll use ggplot2 (included tidyverse) visualize relationship income group index_1, calculates willingness invest energy efficiency measures.üí° Try :
Change variable y-axis another numeric column see plot changes!
code:
ggplot(finsesco, aes(x = income_range, y = index_1)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  labs(
    title = "Willingness to invest in Energy Efficiency Measures by Income Group",
    x = "Income Group",
    y = "Index 1"
  )

heading: Exercise
text: Exercise 01: download RmdUpload via Assignments page Moodle.

heading: 1. Why Data Cleaning Is the Hardest (and Most Important) Step
text:
researchers talk ‚Äúanalysis,‚Äù often imagine fancy models colorful plots.
reality, work happens model fitted: cleaning, organizing, validating raw data. Raw data almost never ready analysis. Surveys come back extra spaces, numbers formatted text, spelling variations, missing responses.
skip cleaning stage, every later step‚Äîsummary statistics, regression, visualization‚Äîquietly give misleading results.‚Äútidy‚Äù meansHadley Wickham defines tidy data three rules:1.variable forms column.
2.observation forms row.
3.value forms single cell.data satisfy rules, can easily filtered, summarized, plotted, joined.
R packages (especially tidyverse) assume data tidy.
cleaning workflow ‚Äôll follow mirrors professional pipeline:

heading: 2. Importing and Inspecting the Dataset
text:
‚Äôll use FinSESCo survey introduced Session 1.
time ‚Äôll pay close attention structure, yet content.R reads filesread_csv() (readr) faster safer base R‚Äôs read.csv():assumes UTF-8 encoding (German umlauts, ‚Ç¨ signs, etc. remain intact).guesses data types scanning sample rows.reports parsing problems instead silently converting text.::() constructs file paths relative R Project root, makes script portable computers operating systems.Now look inside:glimpse() prints one line per variable, showing type first values; summary() gives numeric summaries category counts.Rows: 2,585
Columns: 45
$ Age  ‚Äú32‚Äù, ‚Äú45‚Äù, ‚Äú63‚Äù, ‚Äú28‚Äù, ‚Ä¶
$ Income Range (‚Ç¨)  ‚Äú2,500‚Äì4,000‚Äù, ‚Äú4,000‚Äì6,000‚Äù, ‚Ä¶
$ Gender  ‚ÄúFemale‚Äù, ‚ÄúMale‚Äù, ‚Ä¶can already spot issues:Age stored character, numeric.Column !!!!! contain spaces symbols.multiple inconsistent formats income.cleaning, helps know R thinks type means:Check data types sapply(finsesco, class) ‚Äôre unsure.üí° Tip {-}R‚Äôs type system strict: "42" (character) 42 (numeric).
Whenever arithmetic fails, first check variable‚Äôs type.

heading: 3. Cleaning Column Names and Correcting Types
text:
clean names?Messy names make scripts fragile. Every time use spaces special characters, surround name backticks, e.g.¬†Income Range (‚Ç¨).
janitor::clean_names() automatically fixes converting names lower_snake_case stripping illegal characters.Step--step explanationclean_names() renames columns like Income Range (‚Ç¨) ‚Üí income_range_eur. also ensures uniqueness‚Äîtwo columns share label, appends _2, _3, etc.mutate() lets us change columns -place..integer(age) converts character digits true numbers..factor(income_range) tells R categorical variable.Re-inspect:now see age: int income_range: fct, cleaning worked.üî¥ Important {-}.numeric() .integer() silently turn non-convertible text NA.
Always check many missing values introduced: sum(.na(finsesco$age))

heading: 4. The Logic of Pipes and dplyr Verbs
text: pipe operator %>% passes output one function first argument next. creates readable ‚Äúsentences‚Äù code.Example without pipes:summarise(group_by(finsesco, income_range),           mean(index_1, na.rm = TRUE))Example pipes:second version mirrors human thought: take data ‚Üí group ‚Üí summarise.Let‚Äôs apply :Explanation:select() keeps relevant variables.filter(!.na(index_1)) removes incomplete responses.quantile(index_1, 0.75) finds top 25 % cutoff.mutate() creates logical variable (TRUE/FALSE) indicating whether person top quartile.arrange() orders dataset highest scores appear first.Now can see structure: concise, consistent table analysis.want know verbs dplyr, can download cheat sheet, serves manual using .üìÑ Download dplyr Cheat Sheet (PDF)
code:
finsesco %>%
  group_by(income_range) %>%
  summarise(mean_index_1 = mean(index_1, na.rm = TRUE))
mini <- finsesco %>%
  select(age, gender, income_range, index_1) %>%
  filter(!is.na(index_1)) %>%
  mutate(high_invest_intent = index_1 >= quantile(index_1, 0.75, na.rm = TRUE)) %>%
  arrange(desc(index_1))
head(mini)

heading: 5. Grouping, Summarizing, and Interpreting
text:
Aggregating data first step toward understanding patterns.group_by() adds ‚Äúgrouping‚Äù attribute without changing data .summarise() collapses group one row computing summary statistics.TRUE = 1 FALSE = 0, mean(high_invest_intent) automatically yields proportion TRUEs.Interpretation example:Higher-income respondents show higher mean index_1 larger share high-intention investors, suggesting economic capacity plays role willingness invest.careful: descriptive patterns, causal effects!
haven‚Äôt yet controlled age, ownership, education variables.
code:
mini %>%
  group_by(income_range) %>%
  summarise(n = n(), 
            mean_index_1 = mean(index_1, na.rm = TRUE),
            sd_index_1 = sd(index_1, na.rm = TRUE),
            share_high = mean(high_invest_intent))

heading: 6. Recoding and Creating Ordered Factors
text: Categorical variables intuitive labels logical order.Re-labeling income groupsfct_recode() maps old labels shorter ones.fct_relevel() defines order used plots summaries.Without re-leveling, R might sort alphabetically, putting ‚ÄúMiddle‚Äù ‚ÄúLow‚Äù.Creating age groupscase_when() checks condition sequentially.pipe factor() turns string labels ordered categorical variable, ensuring 18‚Äì29 appears 30‚Äì44 graphs.matters: statistical models interpret factors based order‚Äîdefining explicitly, avoid misleading reference levels later.
code:
finsesco <- finsesco %>%
  mutate(
  income_range = fct_recode(income_range,
  "Low" = "Under ‚Ç¨1,500",
  "Middle" = "‚Ç¨1,500‚Äì‚Ç¨4,000",
  "High" = "Over ‚Ç¨4,000") %>% 
  fct_relevel("Low","Middle","High")
)
finsesco <- finsesco %>%
  mutate(
  age_group = case_when(
  age < 30 ~ "18‚Äì29",
  age < 45 ~ "30‚Äì44",
  age < 60 ~ "45‚Äì59",
  age >= 60 ~ "60+",
  TRUE ~ NA_character_) %>%
  factor(levels = c("18‚Äì29","30‚Äì44","45‚Äì59","60+"))
)

heading: 7. Saving and Versioning Clean Data
text:
Never overwrite raw file. Always save new one documents lineage.becomes baseline later sessions.
later discover error, can regenerate file script rather editing data manually.
code:
clean <- finsesco %>%
  select(age, age_group, gender,
  income_range, index_1)
write_csv(clean, here::here("data", "finsesco_clean.csv"))

heading: 8. Conceptual Reflection
text:
Cleaning data busywork‚Äî‚Äôs modeling reality.
decide ‚Äú‚Ç¨1,500‚Äù means ‚ÄúLow-Income‚Äù ‚Äôre interpreting social categories. replace missing index_1 median, ‚Äôre making assumption underlying distribution. Recognizing choices makes transparent analyst.

heading: Exercise

code:
library(tidyverse)
library(ggplot2)
library(scales)

heading: Session 3
text: applied energy research, figures pictures ‚Äî arguments. good plot answers narrow question (‚Äúdistribution heating behaviour gender?‚Äù), communicates uncertainty, open space next questions. chapter learn turn FinSESCo survey clear, reproducible visual stories using ggplot2. stay descriptive territory: counts, proportions, distributions, grouped comparisons. Session 4 add statistical inference toolbox.

heading: 1. Why visualize first?
text: Energy data time messy, multi-dimensional, context-dependent. modeling, see data:Scale & composition. sample? women low-income prosumers sufficiently represented?Distributions. behaviour indices skewed?Comparisons. self-consumers differ sellers? heating behaviour distributed differently electricity behaviour?Design decisions. audience energy-policy reader (needs proportions clear labels) methods audience (cares distribution shape)?creating figures, follow roadmap: formulate question ‚Üí choose geometry ‚Üí map aesthetics ‚Üí check assumptions ‚Üí interpret ‚Üí export.

heading: 2. Setup: packages, data, and a consistent theme
text: use mostly ggplot2, package inside tidyverse. ‚Äôll use also scales adjust formatting.ggplot2 can adjust aesthetics graph. aesthetics store themes. class, use light accessible default plots.keep single visual language across chapter figures feel related easier compare. good practice research reports.
code:
library(tidyverse)   # ggplot2, dplyr, tidyr, readr, stringr, forcats
library(scales)      # labels: percent_format(), comma_format(), etc.

# Load your dataset (adjust path as in Sessions 1‚Äì2)
# finsesco <- readr::read_csv(here::here("data", "finsesco_clean.csv"))
# or an .rds if you saved it: finsesco <- readr::read_rds("data/finsesco_clean.rds")
#theme_set(theme_minimal(base_size = 12))
#update_geom_defaults("bar", list(linewidth = 0.3))
#update_geom_defaults("point", list(alpha = 0.8))

heading: 3. The Grammar of Graphics
text:
start coding, ‚Äôs important understand makes ggplot2 powerful become standard data visualization R. idea behind ‚ÄúGrammar Graphics‚Äù every plot built basic components ‚Äî data, mappings, layers. Instead thinking ‚Äútypes plots‚Äù (bar chart, boxplot, histogram), describe want show let R assemble figure step step.short, ggplot2 turns process creating graphics language ‚Äî consistent way describing data visualizations.
understand grammar, can combine elements freely build kind plot need research.

heading: 3.1 The three essential building blocks
text: Every ggplot begins three key ingredients:example, compare willingness invest energy efficiency across income groups, write:Take data finsesco.Map income_range variable x-axis (categories: ‚ÄúLow‚Äù, ‚ÄúMedium‚Äù, ‚ÄúHigh‚Äù).Map index_1 y-axis (numeric index measuring willingness invest energy efficiency).Represent relationship boxplots, one income group.output simple already meaningful: box summarizes median spread investment willingness income.
code:
ggplot(clean, aes(x = income_range, y = index_1)) +
  geom_boxplot()

heading: 3.2 Adding More Layers (Step by Step)
text:
One powers ggplot2 can build plots gradually adding layers + operator. layer adds new information improves readability, much like constructing sentence piece piece.Let‚Äôs now create different kind plot: bar chart showing average willingness invest energy efficiency (index_1) across income groups (income_range).Step 1 ‚Äî Compute summary tableBecause bar charts work best pre-computed values, ‚Äôll first calculate mean willingness adapt behaviour heating usage income group.Step 1 ‚Äî Compute summary tableBar charts geom_col() expect pre-computed y-value.
Let‚Äôs calculate mean heating behaviour (0‚Äì100) income group.Step 2 ‚Äî Compute summary tableStep 3 ‚Äî Add color, labels, cleaner layoutLet‚Äôs improve readability coloring bars category, adding value labels, simplifying legend.can clearly see average heating behaviour varies across income levels.
High income bar stands taller, suggests richer households report energy-conscious heating behaviour average.
remember: descriptive patterns ‚Äî show associations, causal effects. Specially case figure, differences groups pronounced. Session 4, ‚Äôll learn add inference assess whether differences statistically meaningful.
code:
ggplot(avg_heat, aes(x = income_range, y = mean_heat)) +
geom_col(fill = "#2C7BB6") +
labs(
title = "Average Heating Behaviour by Income Group",
subtitle = "FinSESCo survey; bars show group means",
x = "Income Group",
y = "Mean Heating Behaviour (0‚Äì100)"
) +
theme_minimal(base_size = 10)
ggplot(avg_heat, aes(x = income_range, y = mean_heat, fill = income_range)) +
geom_col(color = "black", alpha = 0.9) +
geom_text(aes(label = round(mean_heat, 1)), vjust = -0.5, size = 3) +
labs(
title = "Heating Behaviour by Income Group",
subtitle = "Each bar shows the mean of behaviour_heat_scaled within the income category",
x = "Income Group",
y = "Average Heating Behaviour (0‚Äì100)"
) +
scale_fill_brewer(palette = "OrRd") +
theme_minimal(base_size = 10) +
theme(
plot.title = element_text(face = "bold"),
legend.position = "none"
)

heading: 3.3 Why This Matters for Energy Research
text:
Energy research blends behavioural, socioeconomic, technological dimensions.
Visualization plays key role connecting elements translating data insight.
helps :Detect patterns inequalities ‚Äî example, lower-income households show systematically lower heating-efficiency behaviours?Communicate evidence clearly policymakers, stakeholders, public.Explore data modeling, spotting anomalies, trends, subgroup differences.Build intuition distributions relationships running regressions formal tests.Every plot connects back real-world questions FinSESCo dataset:behaves efficiently?invests renewables efficiency?gender, income, ownership relate engagement?Mastering grammar graphics gives consistent visual language answer questions ‚Äî turning raw data meaningful stories energy transition.

heading: 4. Counts and Shares: Who Is in Our Sample?
text:
analyzing behaviour attitudes, first need understand dataset.
groups much larger others, raw counts can misleading.
Proportions (shares) correct allow fair comparisons groups different sizes.section uses FinSESCo dataset (f) explore sample composition counts shares, using ggplot2.

heading: 4.1 Counts by Gender (Absolute)
text:
start simple: count many male female respondents sample.Next, visualize proportion respondents gender.
useful comparing subgroups different sizes, proportions correct imbalances sample counts.
code:
data_complete %>%
  mutate(gender = recode_factor(gender,
                                `0` = "Male",
                                `1` = "Female")) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = gender)) +
  geom_bar(fill = "#0072B2", alpha = 0.8, color = "black") +

  # Add count labels
  geom_text(
    stat = "count",
    aes(label = ..count..),
    vjust = -0.4,
    size = 4,
    fontface = "bold"
  ) +

  labs(
    title = "Sample Composition by Gender",
    subtitle = "Start with counts to see how many observations you actually have",
    x = "Gender",
    y = "Count of Respondents"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 10) +
  expand_limits(y = max(table(data_complete$gender)) * 1.1)
# Recode gender and compute proportions
gender_share <- data_complete %>%
  mutate(gender = recode_factor(gender,
                                `0` = "Male",
                                `1` = "Female")) %>%
  count(gender) %>%
  mutate(share = n / sum(n))

# Plot
ggplot(gender_share, aes(x = 1, y = share, fill = gender)) +
  geom_col(color = "black") +
  
  # Add percentage labels
  geom_text(aes(label = percent(share, accuracy = 1)),
            position = position_stack(vjust = 0.5),
            color = "white", size = 5, fontface = "bold") +
  
  coord_flip() +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = percent_format()) +
  
  # Manual colors: Male = blue, Female = red
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("Male" = "#1F78B4",    # blue
                               "Female" = "#E31A1C")) +  # red
  
  labs(
    title = "Gender Share in the Sample",
    subtitle = "Then you get the proportions",
    x = NULL,
    y = "Share of Respondents",
    fill = "Gender"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 10) +
  theme(
    axis.text.y = element_blank(),
    axis.ticks.y = element_blank(),
    legend.position = "top"
  )

heading: 4.2 Gender Composition Within Prosumer Types
text:
Counts overall shares good starting point, energy research often care demographic composition differs across subgroups. One example, across prosumer types. example?
> Within prosumer type, share respondents male female?answer , compute gender shares inside prosumer_type visualize grouped bar chart.comparing behaviours across ownership groups, need understand group.
Using variables ownership co_ownership, create ownership_type category:Non-owner ‚Üí ownership = 0 co_ownership = 0Sole-owner ‚Üí ownership = 1 co_ownership = 0Co-owner ‚Üí co_ownership = 1 (ownership also 1 case)FinSESCo survey made deliberate effort increase share women, especially female prosumers.
targeted sampling worked well among:Non-owners, andSole-owners,gender proportions relatively balanced closer parity.However, data reveal despite targeted outreach, co-ownership remains male-dominated.
common pattern renewable-energy prosumership research: men tend overrepresented among adopt co-invest technical energy systems PV installations.Understanding imbalance helps frame analysis:co-owners behave differently (e.g., higher heating-efficiency scores),
first ask:co-owners, group male?exactly descriptive visualization essential formal modelling:
shows group prevents misleading interpretations later.
code:
data_extended <- data_complete %>%
  mutate(
    gender = recode_factor(gender,
                           `0` = "Male",
                           `1` = "Female"),
    
    ownership_type = case_when(
      ownership == 0 & co_ownership == 0 ~ "Non-owner",
      ownership == 1 & co_ownership == 0 ~ "Sole-owner",
      co_ownership == 1 ~ "Co-owner",
      TRUE ~ NA_character_
    ) %>% 
      factor(levels = c("Non-owner", "Sole-owner", "Co-owner"))
  )
# Compute gender composition by ownership type
comp_owner <- data_extended %>%
  count(ownership_type, gender) %>%
  group_by(ownership_type) %>%
  mutate(share = n / sum(n)) %>%
  ungroup()

# Plot
ggplot(comp_owner, aes(x = ownership_type, y = share, fill = gender)) +
  geom_col(position = position_dodge(width = 0.8), color = "black") +
  
  # Add percentage labels
  geom_text(
    aes(label = percent(share, accuracy = 1)),
    position = position_dodge(width = 0.8),
    vjust = -0.3,
    size = 4
  ) +
  
  scale_y_continuous(
    labels = percent_format(accuracy = 1),
    expand = expansion(mult = c(0, 0.1))
  ) +
  
  # Consistent colour scheme: Male = blue, Female = red
  scale_fill_manual(
    values = c("Male" = "#1F78B4",
               "Female" = "#E31A1C")
  ) +
  
  labs(
    title = "Gender Composition Across Ownership Types",
    subtitle = "Shares of male and female respondents within non-owners, sole-owners, and co-owners",
    x = "Ownership Type",
    y = "Share of Respondents",
    fill = "Gender"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 10) +
  theme(legend.position = "top")
ggplot(data_complete, aes(x = behaviour_elec_scaled)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 30) +
  labs(
    title = "Distribution of electricity behaviour (0‚Äì100)",
    subtitle = "Check for skew, clumps (heaping), or impossible values",
    x = "Behaviour index (electricity)", y = "Frequency"
  )

heading: 5. Group Summaries with Error Bars (Descriptive Variability)
text:
far, mainly compared distributions (histograms, boxplots).
Sometimes, want compact summary: ‚Äúaverage behaviour group?‚Äùcommon way show :bar (point) group mean, andan error bar variability around mean.Session 3, treat error bars purely descriptive, using something simple :mean ¬± 1 standard error (SE)prosumers average show higher electricity behaviour non-owners?gender gaps large small relative within-group variation?Reading error bars carefullyOverlapping SE bars automatically mean ‚Äúdifference‚Äù.simply show sampling variability around mean.Session 4, learn test differences formally.now, message :
> Error bars give quick sense stable noisy group averages .
code:
mean_se <- function(x) {
  x <- x[!is.na(x)]
  tibble(
    mean = mean(x),
    se   = sd(x) / sqrt(length(x))
  )
}

sum_e <- data_extended %>%
  mutate(
    gender = recode_factor(
      gender,
      `0` = "Male",
      `1` = "Female"
    )
  ) %>%
  group_by(ownership_type, gender) %>%
  summarise(
    mean_se(behaviour_elec_scaled),
    .groups = "drop"
  )

ggplot(sum_e, aes(x = ownership_type, y = mean, fill = gender)) +
  geom_col(position = position_dodge(width = 0.8), color = "black") +
  geom_errorbar(
    aes(ymin = mean - se, ymax = mean + se),
    width = 0.2,
    position = position_dodge(width = 0.8)
  ) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("Male" = "#1F78B4", "Female" = "#E31A1C")) +
  labs(
    title = "Electricity Behaviour: Descriptive Group Means (¬±1 SE)",
    subtitle = "Use for visual summaries only; formal inference comes next session",
    x = "Ownership Type",
    y = "Mean Behaviour (0‚Äì100)",
    fill = "Gender"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 10)

heading: 6. Proportions: Binary Outcomes Policy Cares About
text:
Many policy questions yes/:‚Äúshare households high willingness invest heating?‚Äù‚Äúshare respondents report efficient behaviour?‚Äùanswer questions, often:Define threshold scale (e.g., ‚Äúhigh‚Äù = score ‚â• 7 0‚Äì10 scale).Create binary variable (1 = high, 0 = high).Compute proportion 1s group (e.g., gender prosumer type).Plot proportions bars percentage labels.yields statements policymakers understand easily, :‚ÄúAmong co-owners, 42% report high willingness invest heating, compared 25% among non-owners.‚Äùüß™ Sensitivity checkThresholds partly researcher choices.
change cutoff (e.g., 6 vs.¬†7 vs.¬†8) conclusions change dramatically, :mention interpretation, andbe transparent robustness results.
code:
library(dplyr)
library(forcats)
library(ggplot2)
library(scales)

bin <- data_extended %>%
  mutate(
    gender = recode_factor(
      gender,
      `0` = "Male",
      `1` = "Female"
    ),
    # IMPORTANT: if your variable has another name, replace index_1 below
    high_inv_index1 = inv_ee_heat_scaled_2 >= 70   # threshold can be adjusted
  ) %>%
  filter(!is.na(high_inv_index1))

p_grp <- bin %>%
  group_by(gender, ownership_type) %>%
  summarise(
    p = mean(high_inv_index1),
    n = n(),
    .groups = "drop"
  ) %>%
  mutate(label = scales::percent(p, accuracy = 1))

ggplot(p_grp, aes(x = ownership_type, y = p, fill = gender)) +
  geom_col(position = position_dodge(width = 0.8), color = "black") +
  geom_text(
    aes(label = label),
    position = position_dodge(width = 0.8),
    vjust = -0.4,
    size = 3.5
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(
    labels = scales::percent_format(),
    limits = c(0, 1)
  ) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("Male" = "#1F78B4", "Female" = "#E31A1C")) +
  labs(
    title = "Share with High Willingness to Invest in Energy Efficiency (> 70 in a scale of 100)",
    subtitle = "Proportions are directly interpretable for policy audiences",
    x = "Ownership Type",
    y = "Proportion of High-Investment Respondents",
    fill = "Gender"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 10) +
  theme(legend.position = "top")

heading: 7. Facets: Many Comparisons, One Visual Grammar
text:
Sometimes need compare relationship across many subgroups.
example:Heating behaviour income, separately prosumer type.Electricity behaviour gender, separately income group.Facets allow :keep axes plot type,give subgroup panel.helps reader compare structures, just numbers.
can visually scan across panels ask:income gradient look similar non-owners self-consumers?gap prosumers non-prosumers appear income groups high income?Facets powerful way show heterogeneity without overcrowding single plot.
code:
ggplot(data_extended, aes(x = income_range, y = behaviour_heat_scaled)) +
  geom_boxplot(outlier.alpha = 0.25) +
  facet_wrap(~ ownership_type) +
  labs(
    title = "Heating Behaviour by Income and Ownership Type",
    subtitle = "Facets preserve structure; rotate labels when categories are long",
    x = "Income Range",
    y = "Behaviour (0‚Äì100)"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 10) +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 30, hjust = 1))

heading: 8. Stacked vs.¬†Dodged vs.¬†100% Bars: Which Composition View?
text: underlying data (e.g., counts men women prosumer type) can shown three main ways.emphasizes different message:
code:
base_tab <- data_extended %>%
  mutate(
    gender = recode_factor(
      gender,
      `0` = "Male",
      `1` = "Female"
    )
  ) %>%
  count(ownership_type, gender) %>%
  group_by(ownership_type) %>%
  mutate(p = n / sum(n)) %>%
  ungroup()

heading: 8.1 Stacked Counts
text: Stacked bars x-axis (e.g., prosumer types) show:total group size (bar height), andinternal composition (segments gender).Use :care many group.
code:
ggplot(base_tab, aes(x = ownership_type, y = n, fill = gender)) +
  geom_col(color = "black") +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("Male" = "#1F78B4", "Female" = "#E31A1C")) +
  labs(
    title = "Stacked Counts by Ownership Type and Gender",
    x = "Ownership Type",
    y = "Count of Respondents",
    fill = "Gender"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 10)

heading: 8.2 Dodged (Side-by-Side) Counts
text: Bars group (e.g., gender) placed side side category:emphasizes comparisons magnitude across groups,e.g., ‚Äúfemale self-consumers male self-consumers?‚ÄùUse :want clearly compare levels two groups across categories.
code:
ggplot(base_tab, aes(x = ownership_type, y = n, fill = gender)) +
  geom_col(position = position_dodge(width = 0.8), color = "black") +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("Male" = "#1F78B4", "Female" = "#E31A1C")) +
  labs(
    title = "Dodged Counts by Ownership Type and Gender",
    x = "Ownership Type",
    y = "Count of Respondents",
    fill = "Gender"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 10)

heading: 8.3 100% (Standardized) Bars
text: bar height (100%) share (percentage) inside changes:removes differences total sample size,focuses solely composition (e.g., gender mix within prosumer type).Use :want highlight relative composition, independent group size.Rule thumbUse stacked counts emphasize total capacity size.Use dodged bars compare group magnitudes directly.Use 100% bars highlight composition (shares) independent size.
code:
ggplot(base_tab, aes(x = ownership_type, y = p, fill = gender)) +
  geom_col(position = "fill", color = "black") +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent_format()) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("Male" = "#1F78B4", "Female" = "#E31A1C")) +
  labs(
    title = "100% Bars: Gender Composition Within Ownership Types",
    x = "Ownership Type",
    y = "Share of Respondents",
    fill = "Gender"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 10)

heading: 9. Ordering Categories for Meaning
text:
default, R often orders categories alphabetically, can obscure interesting patterns.
energy research, meaningful order often exists, example:income: Low ‚Üí Medium ‚Üí Highprosumer types ordered mean behaviour investment willingnessReordering factors helps plot align story:order prosumer types lowest highest mean electricity behaviour,
left--right progression matches idea increasing gradient.Design heuristic:Whenever plot invites left--right reading (‚Äúleast‚Äù ‚Äú‚Äù, ‚Äúlow‚Äù ‚Äúhigh‚Äù),
consider reordering categories according substantive statistic (e.g., mean behaviour).
code:
#1. Compute order as a simple character vector
ord <- data_extended %>%
  group_by(ownership_type) %>%
  summarise(
    m = mean(behaviour_elec_scaled, na.rm = TRUE),
    .groups = "drop"
  ) %>%
  arrange(m) %>%                   # from lower to higher mean behaviour
  pull(ownership_type) %>%
  as.character()                   # ensure it's a plain character vector

# 2. Relevel ownership_type using that order
data_extended_ord <- data_extended %>%
  mutate(
    ownership_type = fct_relevel(as.factor(ownership_type), ord)
  )

# 3. Plot
ggplot(data_extended_ord, aes(x = ownership_type)) +
  geom_bar(fill = "#0072B2", alpha = 0.8, color = "black") +
  labs(
    title = "Ownership Types Ordered by Mean Electricity Behaviour",
    subtitle = "Ordering supports the narrative (from lower to higher mean behaviour)",
    x = NULL,
    y = "Count of Respondents"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 10) +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 30, hjust = 1))

heading: 10. Quick Plot Decision Guide
text:
wrap Session 3, compact guide:One numeric variable ‚Üí histogram density (distribution shape).Numeric vs.¬†category ‚Üí boxplot, mean + error bars (group comparison).Counts across categories ‚Üí bar chart (stacked dodged).Shares / composition ‚Üí 100% bar chart.Many subgroups ‚Üí facets.Order matters ‚Üí reorder factors support narrative.Session 4, take next step:
moving descriptive visuals statistical inference, ask whether patterns see likely reflect real differences just sampling noise.

heading: Exercise
text: Exercise 03: Download PDFUpload via Assignments page Moodle.

heading: Session 4
text: now, learned explore dataset, inspect variables, filter, select, visualise data. session, move basic statistics, form backbone data-driven research energy transition.Basic statistics help answer questions :data look like? patterns?different prosumer groups behaving differently?difference large enough meaningful just random noise?two variables related systematic way?ownership types behave differently electricity heating?session gives ‚Äúcore toolkit‚Äù need moving advanced methods like ANCOVA regression. Everything learn used later seminar.
code:
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(DescTools)

heading: 1. Why Basic Statistics Matter
text:
build model ‚Äî regression, ANCOVA, machine learning ‚Äî must understand data . skip step, becomes easy misinterpret results overlook basic data quality problems.Basic statistics help :Detect errors early
Strange means, impossible minimum maximum values, odd spikes distribution can indicate coding errors, wrong units, inconsistent data entry.Detect errors early
Strange means, impossible minimum maximum values, odd spikes distribution can indicate coding errors, wrong units, inconsistent data entry.Understand shape behaviour
Energy behaviour, consumption, investment willingness rarely follow perfect bell-shaped (normal) distribution. often show skewness, heavy tails, clusters specific subgroups (e.g., high-income prosumers).Understand shape behaviour
Energy behaviour, consumption, investment willingness rarely follow perfect bell-shaped (normal) distribution. often show skewness, heavy tails, clusters specific subgroups (e.g., high-income prosumers).Ask precise questions
Instead asking ‚Äúprosumers behave differently?‚Äù, can refine question ‚Äútypes prosumers differ, much, behaviours?‚ÄùAsk precise questions
Instead asking ‚Äúprosumers behave differently?‚Äù, can refine question ‚Äútypes prosumers differ, much, behaviours?‚Äùshort: descriptive statistics ‚Äúpreliminary step‚Äù rush . part analysis help build credible story data.

heading: 2. Central Tendency
text:
Central tendency measures describe ‚Äúmiddle‚Äù data lies. measure emphasises different aspect middle.Mean (average)
Add values divide number observations. intuitive widely used, sensitive extreme values (outliers).Mean (average)
Add values divide number observations. intuitive widely used, sensitive extreme values (outliers).Median
value sits exactly middle sort data smallest largest. median robust outliers thus often informative skewed variables income, energy bills, certain behavioural indices.Median
value sits exactly middle sort data smallest largest. median robust outliers thus often informative skewed variables income, energy bills, certain behavioural indices.Mode
frequent value. measure useful categorical variables (e.g.¬†common ownership type) variables particular score especially common.Mode
frequent value. measure useful categorical variables (e.g.¬†common ownership type) variables particular score especially common.FinSESCo dataset, often see mean median differ. mean considerably higher median, suggests right-skewed distribution minority high values.
code:
mean(data_extended$behaviour_elec, na.rm = TRUE)## [1] 1.277922
median(data_extended$behaviour_elec, na.rm = TRUE)## [1] 1.297061
Mode(data_extended$behaviour_elec, na.rm = TRUE)## [1] 1.338566
## attr(,"freq")
## [1] 629

heading: 3. Measures of Spread
text:
Central tendency tells centre distribution, spread data around centre. Two groups can mean different patterns terms dispersion.Key measures spread include:Standard Deviation (SD)
Indicates far, average, observations lie mean. small SD means values tightly clustered; large SD means values spread .Standard Deviation (SD)
Indicates far, average, observations lie mean. small SD means values tightly clustered; large SD means values spread .Interquartile Range (IQR)
difference 75th 25th percentile. focuses ‚Äúmiddle 50%‚Äù data robust extreme outliers, making particularly useful skewed noisy variables.Interquartile Range (IQR)
difference 75th 25th percentile. focuses ‚Äúmiddle 50%‚Äù data robust extreme outliers, making particularly useful skewed noisy variables.Range (minimum maximum)
simplest measure: smallest largest values dataset. Helpful quickly spot obvious errors (e.g., negative household size, impossible index values).Range (minimum maximum)
simplest measure: smallest largest values dataset. Helpful quickly spot obvious errors (e.g., negative household size, impossible index values).energy behaviour variables, spread important reveals whether behaviour relatively homogeneous across households whether lot heterogeneity later models need explain.
code:
sd(data_extended$behaviour_heat, na.rm = TRUE)## [1] 0.08744716
IQR(data_extended$behaviour_heat, na.rm = TRUE)## [1] 0.09512417
range(data_extended$behaviour_heat, na.rm = TRUE)## [1] 0.8325546 1.3385662

heading: 4. Distributions
text:
distribution describes often possible value variable occurs. Looking distributions crucial understanding shape structure data.Two simple powerful visual tools :Histograms
show many observations fall ‚Äúbin‚Äù values. histogram, can see whether variable symmetric, skewed, unimodal, multimodal.Boxplots
summarise distribution using median, quartiles, potential outliers. Boxplots compact, making useful comparing several groups side side.Typical patterns context:Behaviour consumption variables often right-skewed (many households moderate values, fewer high values), case see contrary!Index variables based survey responses can clumped around specific values (e.g., many people agreeing strongly agreeing).Understanding distribution helps decide whether certain transformations robust methods might needed later whether particular values examined closely.
code:
data_extended %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = behaviour_elec)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 30, fill = "#0072B2", alpha = 0.8) +
  labs(
    title = "Distribution of Electricity Behaviour Index",
    x = "Electricity Behaviour Index",
    y = "Count of Households"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()
ggplot(data_extended, aes(y = behaviour_elec)) +
  geom_boxplot(fill = "#0072B2", alpha = 0.8) +
  labs(
    title = "Boxplot of Electricity Behaviour Index",
    y = "Electricity Behaviour Index"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()

heading: 5. Grouped Descriptive Statistics
text: Group summaries allow compare basic statistics across categories ownership type, gender, income group, region.Typical questions:mean electricity behaviour differ across ownership types?standard deviation higher non-owners prosumers?sample sizes balanced, one group much smaller?computing grouped means, standard deviations, counts, can:Identify groups behave similarly differently.Check whether categories -represented.Build intuition later hypothesis tests (t-tests, ANOVA, ANCOVA).practice, might find certain prosumer categories show higher mean engagement lower variability, indicating consistently engaged group.
code:
data_extended %>%
  group_by(ownership_type) %>%
  summarise(
    mean_elec = mean(behaviour_elec, na.rm = TRUE),
    sd_elec   = sd(behaviour_elec, na.rm = TRUE),
    n         = sum(!is.na(behaviour_elec))
  )

heading: 6. Cross-tabulations
text: Cross-tabulations (contingency tables) used summarising relationship two categorical variables.Examples FinSESCo:Gender ownership typeIncome group prosumer statusRegion type heating systemA cross-tabulation table shows counts, proportions can added make comparisons easier. example, proportions column help answer questions :Within ownership type, share respondents women?Within prosumer category, proportion belongs specific income bracket?important later differences behaviour groups might partly reflect differences composition. one prosumer group heavily male another heavily female, gender confounding factor behavioural comparisons.
code:
tab_gender_own <- table(data_extended$gender, data_extended$ownership_type)
tab_gender_own##         
##          Non-owner Sole-owner Co-owner
##   Male         721        197      267
##   Female       939        276      185
prop.table(tab_gender_own, margin = 2)##         
##          Non-owner Sole-owner  Co-owner
##   Male   0.4343373  0.4164905 0.5907080
##   Female 0.5656627  0.5835095 0.4092920

heading: 7. Correlation
text: Correlation measures strongly two numeric variables move together linear fashion.positive correlation means higher values one variable tend associated higher values .negative correlation means higher values one variable tend associated lower values .value near zero suggests little linear relationship.Correlation useful first diagnostic tool see variables appear related. context energy research, might explore correlations :Behavioural indices electricity vs heating,Behavioural indices income education,Investment willingness past energy-related actions.However, important remember: correlation imply causation. strong correlation can driven underlying third variable (e.g., income, age, dwelling type). Correlation starting point formulate hypotheses, final proof causal effect.
code:
cor(
  data_extended$behaviour_elec,
  data_extended$inv_ee_elec_scaled_2,
  use = "complete.obs"
)## [1] 0.2319637
data_extended %>%
  select(behaviour_elec, behaviour_heat, inv_ee_elec_scaled_2) %>%
  cor(use = "pairwise.complete.obs")##                      behaviour_elec behaviour_heat inv_ee_elec_scaled_2
## behaviour_elec            1.0000000      0.5658498            0.2319637
## behaviour_heat            0.5658498      1.0000000            0.2827447
## inv_ee_elec_scaled_2      0.2319637      0.2827447            1.0000000

heading: 8. Comparing Two Groups: t-test
text: t-test used want compare means two groups numeric variable. answers question:average values Group Group B genuinely different, difference explained random variation?typically use independent-samples t-test :independent variable exactly two categories (e.g.¬†men vs women, owners vs non-owners).dependent variable numeric (e.g.¬†index energy behaviour willingness invest).energy research, typical examples include:Comparing average electricity behaviour men women.Comparing average heating behaviour owners tenants.Comparing investment willingness prosumers non-prosumers.t-test output provides:estimated difference group means.p-value indicating whether difference statistically significant.confidence interval showing range plausible values difference.p-value chosen threshold (commonly 0.05) confidence interval include zero, conclude two groups differ average behaviour.use t-test two groups, outcome categorical, samples extremely small unbalanced. cases, methods (e.g.¬†ANOVA chi-square tests) appropriate.
code:
t.test(behaviour_elec ~ gender, data = data_extended)## 
##  Welch Two Sample t-test
## 
## data:  behaviour_elec by gender
## t = 5.7401, df = 2554.2, p-value = 1.058e-08
## alternative hypothesis: true difference in means between group Male and group Female is not equal to 0
## 95 percent confidence interval:
##  0.01059520 0.02159012
## sample estimates:
##   mean in group Male mean in group Female 
##             1.286652             1.270559

heading: 9. Comparing More Than Two Groups: ANOVA
text: want compare means three groups numeric outcome, standard approach ANOVA (Analysis Variance).Typical use cases seminar include questions :different ownership categories (e.g.¬†non-owners, sellers, self-consumers, consumer-sellers) exhibit different levels electricity behaviour?investment willingness differ across several income groups?heating behaviour scores different across education categories?Conceptually, ANOVA tests whether variability group means large relative variability within groups. -group variation much larger, suggests group membership associated meaningful differences outcome.key result ANOVA F-test corresponding p-value:p-value threshold (e.g.¬†0.05), conclude least one group mean differs others.p-value threshold, conclude observed differences group means compatible random variation.ANOVA tells ‚Äúsomewhere‚Äù among groups difference, exactly pairs groups differ. , use post-hoc tests Tukey‚Äôs HSD, compare group means pairwise controlling multiple comparisons.use ANOVA rather series t-tests running many t-tests inflates probability false positives. ANOVA provides single, coherent test overall group effect.
code:
anova_model <- aov(behaviour_elec ~ ownership_type, data = data_extended)
summary(anova_model)##                  Df Sum Sq  Mean Sq F value Pr(>F)  
## ownership_type    2  0.037 0.018379   3.569 0.0283 *
## Residuals      2565 13.207 0.005149                 
## ---
## Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
## 17 observations deleted due to missingness
TukeyHSD(anova_model)##   Tukey multiple comparisons of means
##     95% family-wise confidence level
## 
## Fit: aov(formula = behaviour_elec ~ ownership_type, data = data_extended)
## 
## $ownership_type
##                             diff           lwr        upr     p adj
## Sole-owner-Non-owner 0.006816653 -0.0019767348 0.01561004 0.1638919
## Co-owner-Non-owner   0.008803242 -0.0001404581 0.01774694 0.0548369
## Co-owner-Sole-owner  0.001986588 -0.0090997447 0.01307292 0.9072697

heading: 10. Visualising Group Differences
text: Numerical outputs important, visualisations often make group differences easier grasp communicate.common approach plot:mean outcome group bar point.Error bars representing uncertainty around mean, often using standard errors confidence intervals.plots help answer visually:groups appear higher lower outcome?uncertainty intervals overlap strongly, suggesting small uncertain differences?groups based small sample sizes (indicated wide bars points)?energy-behaviour context, might show mean electricity behaviour ownership group error bars. Even without looking detailed ANOVA output, plot give quick sense whether policies interventions might need target specific groups.
code:
data_extended %>%
  group_by(ownership_type) %>%
  summarise(
    m  = mean(inv_ee_elec_scaled, na.rm = TRUE),
    se = sd(inv_ee_elec_scaled, na.rm = TRUE) / sqrt(sum(!is.na(inv_ee_elec_scaled)))
  ) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = ownership_type, y = m)) +
    geom_col(fill = "#0072B2", alpha = 0.8) +
    geom_errorbar(aes(ymin = m - se, ymax = m + se), width = 0.2) +
    labs(
      title = "Willingness to invest in electricity efficiency measures by Ownership Type",
      x = "Ownership Type",
      y = "Mean Investment Behaviour (¬± SE)"
    ) +
    theme_minimal()

heading: 11. Interpretation Checklist
text:
Whenever interpret statistical results (t-test, ANOVA, correlations), helps follow simple checklist:result statistically significant?
Look p-value, also understand significance depends sample size.result statistically significant?
